messageBody:
Hi Danno,

On 8/4/06, DanHinojosa <newsreader@...> wrote:
> VelocityContext context = new VelocityContext();
> context.put("requestMap", requestMap);
> StringWriter w = new StringWriter();
> Velocity.mergeTemplate("mytemplate.vm", "UTF-8", context, w);
> String text = w.toString();
>
> InitialContext ic = new InitialContext();
> Session session = (Session) ic.find("mail/MailSource");
> Message msg = new MimeMessage(session);
> msg.setContent(text, "text/plain");
>
> If I create a testFoo method to test this I am out of luck. This is
> because the Velocity Context relies on an underlying classloader. The
> InitialContext relies on an underlying Java EE context. Again, this
> is a UNIT TEST, and not an integration or system test. So what is the
> best way to do get good test coverage on this? Shall I extract the
> code into another class that I can inject my InitialContext mocks and
> my VelocityContext mocks through there?

I'm not sure what you mean by VelocityContext relying on an underlying
classloader(?) but I'd like to add a little something about mocking
the InitialContext to Joakim's points about abstracting things a bit.

The open source MockEJB project (http://www.mockejb.org) includes a
handy little class named "MockContextFactory". With that, you can do
something like this:

import org.mockejb.jndi.MockContextFactory;

public class TestingJndiStuffWithMockContextFactory {
@Before
public void initializeMockInitialContext() {
MockContextFactory.setAsInitial();

// bind whatever objects you want into the JNDI tree
InitialContext context = new InitialContext();
context.bind("whatever", new MockWhatever());
}

@After
public void resetInitialContext() {
MockContextFactory.revertSetAsInitial();
}
}


-Lasse-
